annotation.TEXT: Just to note: I don't recommend triggering this boss until you've gotten some of the other Ariel items first. Their protection against the Stone status really helps out in this fight.

Admittedly, I did luck out on this battle to some extent. Eraqus normally spams missiles after being attacked, which cover a large area and can potentially hit all of your characters (or even one character multiple times). This time however, he seemed content to spam one of his much stranger - albeit weaker abilities.

Through-out the course of the final chapter, if you run away 95 times, you'll be presented with that generous little message. This is followed by a count-down each time you flee a fight - and once you reach 100, the optional boss emerges.

Eraqus isn't quite as overpowered as Amlucretia, but he can be just as annoying if you come into this fight unprepared. Much like the aforementioned god-fish, Eraqus has very high defense, but he doesn't have as much HP. Certain level 16 skills such as Sundown's Hurricane Shot and Pogo's Dodegesden are the only things capable of dealing considerable damage to this guy.

Moving ahead again, it's time to complete the last two bonus dungeons - starting with the Dungeon of Time. If you have Sundown in your party, you can find this dungeon through some trees next to the Naorigusa patch's entrance (the place where you can recruit Pogo).
With this done, there's just one more character to recruit - along with completing their bonus dungeon.

As said before, the Jaggy Eggs aren't so much difficult as they are annoying. Their attacks can be rather strong, but if you have Cube with you, his "High Speed OP" can generally ease up most of the damage these things cause. Each one also has considerably less HP when compared to the other bosses (about 300 or so).

Space Phage is the only threatening move these things have (as obviously seen here). They can only use it if you happen to be far away from them, but they generally tend to prefer Spin Drive and Laser Sonic over this move.

Once all eight bells go off, you'll be forced into a boss fight. Beating it nets you the Ariel Glove, and the fight itself isn't all that difficult (just annoying). Aside from maybe rushing to get Sundown's ultimate weapon before the fight (as seen here), you don't have too much to fear if your party is leveled up enough.

Now would also be a good time to mention the Ariel Equipment. There's five pieces of Ariel items in total, all of which are obtained by beating these optional bosses. Aside from giving a nice stat boost, the Ariel items also help protect from the Stone/Stun status, which helps out immensely for some of the later fights.

So once again, for the sake of convenience, I'll transition ahead to when I've farmed a decent amount of these keys. I'll also be skipping around in the actual dungeon somewhat (since I honestly got lost quite a few times while looking for the more important keys that grant access to Oboro's ultimate weapon).

Provided you have a some of the Ariel items on your characters, Death Prophet is one of the easier optional bosses. His primary move can turn you to stone, but with this effect made useless by the Ariel equipment, the attack itself is very weak. The only other threatening move he has is "Dimensional Rift," which can easily be brushed off with one use of the Medicine Box.

With Oboro on the team, we can not only get the ever-important Medicine Box, but access the final dungeon - the Dungeon of Keys. The dungeon itself is found back at the village just outside the castle, and is easily my least favorite of these areas.
For the sake of convenience once again, I'll skip ahead to when all eight bells have gone off.

As per suggested by its name, every door in the Dungeon of Keys is locked. Most of them can only be opened by using the "Rusted Key," an item dropped from a Ninja-based enemy that occasionally shows up here. Here-in lies my issues with this dungeon: Not only is the process for grinding these keys tedious (due to the presence of other enemies), but the dungeon itself is a maze that's mostly composed of similar looking rooms.

This dungeon's gimmick is pretty straight-forward: There are no random encounters here, but there is something of a time limit. You have eight "bells" to find Sundown's ultimate weapon and then make your way back to the entrance. As each bell goes off, the screen darkens and it gets harder to make your way through the dungeon.

With the last dungeon out of the way, there's only a few things left to do in the whole game: Find and beat the last two optional bosses, and then defeat Odio. I have just enough time to do one of the former, mainly one I mentioned before that emerges by running from fights.

Time for a slight flashback of sorts. I mentioned before that I forgot to show some footage of a secret boss found back at Cube's dungeon. For completion purposes and to avoid further confusion, I'm showing it at the start of this segment. Just to note - this was done before I went to Pogo's dungeon, hence why my stats and items might be a bit inconsistent here.
